dict.string: A FULL ANGLE is defined as an ordered pair of two lines, u and v, denoted by ∠[u,v].
∠[u,v] = ∠[0] iff u ∥ v (including u = v).
∠[u,s] + ∠[s,v] = ∠[u,v]. This rule splits an angle into two or more angles.
If AC = BC, we have ∠[ABC] = ∠[CAB]. Conversely, if ∠[ABC] = ∠[CAB], then AB = AC or A, B and C are colinear.
Points A, B, C and D are cyclic iff ∠[ABC] = ∠[ADC].
If Cyclic(A,B,M,N), then ∠[AB, AM] = ∠[BN, NM]. Hence, ∠[AB, CD] = ∠[AB, AM] + ∠[AM, CD] = ∠[BN, NM] + ∠[AM, CD].
Unknown rule
If AB is the diameter of the circumcircle of triangle ABC and D is on the circumcircle, then for any line FG, we have ∠[CD, FG] = ∠[DBA] + ∠[ACB] + ∠[BC, FG]].
If O is the intersection of Circle(O1; O, P1, P3, I) and Circle(O2; O, P2, P4, J) and Colinear(O, I, J), then ∠[P1O, OP2] = ∠[P1P2, IP3] + ∠[JP4, P2P4].
If O is the circumcenter of triangle ABC, then ∠[BOC] = 2×∠[BAC].
For Circle(O, A, B, C, D), if O is the intersection of AD and BC, then ∠[AOB] = 2×∠[CDA].
For Circle(O; A, B), O is the center of circle, we have ∠[OAB] = ∠[ABO].
If ABE is a right triangle and O is the midpoint of the hypotenuse AB, then for any line CD, we have ∠[AB, CD] = ∠[BAE] + ∠[1] + ∠[BE, CD]
For Circle(O; A, B, C) with D as midpoint of BC, ∠[AB, EF] = ∠[BOD] + ∠[AC, EF].
For Circle(O; A, B, F) with E as midpoint of AF, ∠[AB, CD] = ∠[EOA] + ∠[BF, CD].
If G is the orthocenter of A, B, C, ∠[AE, HI] = ∠[AE, BE] + ∠[BE, HI] = ∠[1] + ∠[BE, HI]
If A is the incenter of P2, K, I, ∠[AB, CD] = ∠[AB, BK] + ∠[BK, CD] = ∠[1] + ∠[KI, KA] + ∠[IA, IK] + ∠[BK, CD].
Equal Angle found in Geometry Deductive Database.
If AB ⊥ AC and AB = AC, then ∠[AB, AC] = 2×∠[AB,BC].
If AB ⊥ AC and AB = AC, then 2×∠[AB,DE] = 2×∠[AB,BC] + 2×∠[BC,DE] = ∠[1] + 2×∠[BC,DE].
If OB // DE and A is on Circle(O; B), then 2×∠[AB, DE] = ∠[OA,OB].
A is on Circle(O; B), then 2×∠[AB, DE] = ∠[OA,OB] + 2×∠[OA,DE].
CD is a diameter of Circle(A, B, C, D), AB ⊥ CD, then 2×∠[DB,BA] = ∠[0].
A, B, C, D, E are cyclic and AC = AB, then 2×∠[AB, BC] = ∠[CE, ED].
If A, B, E, F, G are cyclic and AE = AF, then 2×∠[AB, CD] = 2×∠[BE, CD] + ∠[EG, GF].
If AB = AC = BC, i.e., triangle ABC is an equilateral triangle, then 3×∠[AB, BC] = ∠[0].
